Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Biophysical Control of Cardiac Differentiation in Patient Specific Cardiac Stem Cells

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
PI: Black, Lauren D.
Proposal Number: 1351241
Title: CAREER: Biophysical Control of Cardiac Differentiation in Patient Specific Cardiac Stem Cells

Current methods for deriving functional cardiac muscle cells from patient-specific stem cells have resulted in low efficiency in part because they only mimic the chemical signaling aspect of the environment of the cell present in the body. The studies described in this proposal seek to enhance our understanding of how patient-specific stem cells can be influenced to differentiate to cardiac muscle cells by understanding how the biophysical and biochemical environment external to the cells affects the ability of resident stem cells in the heart to turn into cardiac muscle. This work is particularly relevant because many of the current methods for differentiation of stem cells to cardiac muscle cells involve the use of growth factors and are highly inefficient. If successful, the proposed studies will be impactful in terms of advancing fundamental science, and for having significant potential in bringing medical applications closer to the clinic. Education and outreach activities are well integrated with the proposed research and involve local and inner city high schools as well as curriculum development for undergraduate and graduate students.

Recently, ckit+ cardiac progenitor cells (CPCs) have been singled out as one of the most promising sources of cells for cardiac repair because of their relative abundance, ease of isolation and their ability to differentiate into the three major cells types in the heart: smooth muscle cells endothelial cells and cardiomyocytes (CMs). The efficiency of differentiation of CPCs to functional CMs with standard soluble factor-based protocols has been low, but co-culture with native CMs or implantation in vivo have demonstrated an enhanced effect, indicating that other factors in the tissue microenvironment may be important for promoting cardiac differentiation of CPCs. The overall hypothesis of this proposal is that integrating substrate properties and bioelectric signaling will lead to enhancements in functional differentiation of pediatric patient derived CPCs. This hypothesis will be tested by: 1) establishing a baseline of cardiac differentiation of clonal populations of ckit+ CPCs derived from pediatric patients using growth factor or small molecule based differentiation protocols; 2) assessing the individual effects of substrate stiffness, substrate composition and resting membrane potential on cardiac differentiation of CPC clones and elucidate the specific mechanotransductive and differentiation pathways involved; and 3) determining the interactive effects of biophysical and bioelectric signaling in promoting the development of functional CMs from ckit+ CPCs. To carry out these aims, techniques previously developed in the PI's lab will be used to isolate/ characterize cardiac extracellular matrix, create substrates with different mechanical properties, and control resting membrane potential of cells. Functional differentiation of cells will be assessed via gene and protein expression, as well as calcium transient imaging and contraction force measurements via dynamic traction force microscopy.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Project outcomes that address the intellectual merit and broader impacts of the work:

The goal of this project was to assess the role that physical forces, biochemical interactions with proteins and electrical signaling play in the differentiation of patient specific cardiac stem cells derived from pediatric subjects undergoing repair of congenital heart defects. Cardiac stem cells were isolated from 5 patients with a range of ages and congenital defect type and characterized for their ability to grow in the lab as well as for their ability to be converted into more specialized cells within the heart, including cardiac muscle cells and the cells relevant to forming blood vessels. Once these cells were characterized at baseline, they were then cultured on gel surfaces of different stiffnesses that were coated with single proteins from the extracellular matrix (e.g. collagen), as well as whole extracellular matrix from hearts at different ages. We then assessed the growth and ability of the cells to be converted into more specialized cells as a function of the culture surface properties (mechanical stiffness and composition of the proteins on the surface) to understand the role that the ECM may play in the cells conversion to cardiac muscle cells and cells that makeup the blood vessels. What we found is that the stiffness and protein coatings had an interactive effect in promoting cardiac stem cell specialization and that this specialization was more towards blood vessel cells than cardiac muscle cells. 

In a separate set of experiment we also sought to study the role of electrical signals in promoting cardiac stem cell differentiation. This concept arose from the fact that all cells have an electrical potential, and that this potential changes as cells become more specialized. We sought to force this change in potential in the cardiac stem cells from patients by treating the cells with various drugs that effect the channels in the membrane that allow charged molecules to pass through. By blocking or activating these channels we can decrease or increase the amount of charged molecules passing into the cell and thus alter the cellular electrical potential. Whatthese studies was tat alterations in electrical potential were also sufficient enough to change the cell specialization from the patient specific cardiac stem cells. 

In a final set of experiments we determined whether there were any interactive effects when these two stimuli (culture surface properties and electrical signaling) were combined in one culture. We found that there were significant interactions between the two stimuli and are currently finalizing data analysis to determine whether one stimuli is more dominant in driving the specialization of patient specific cardiac stem cells. 

In terms of the Broader Impacts outcomes of this proposal there are two key ones to report on. The first is that over 100 high school students were trained in laboratory research techniques and exposed to Biomedical Engineering as part of the high school summer research program proposed in this grant. These students have gone on to college, many have majored in Biology or Biomedical Engineering and most have continued in doing research as they reach the collegiate level. The other major outcome is that several modules were developed for course teaching both undergraduate and graduate students at Tufts University, including the implementation of  active learning approaches (and a cardiac development/ congenital heart defect case study) for a mixed graduate/ undergraduate quantitative physiology course taught by the PI. 

Other products that have resulted from the grant: 

Beyond the manuscripts already published related to this work, several other products have been generated. These include: 1) several posters presented at conferences related to the project, 2) several posters generated by high school students participating in the outreach program, 3) survey data related t the high school program and its effectiveness, and 4)  lectures related to the research for a variety of classes at Tufts in the Biomedical Engineering department as well as seminars for visits at other universities. 

Anticipated publication of remaining project results:

While we have published several manuscripts related to this project to date we anticipate at least another three manuscripts to be submitted for publication in the next 6 months. These include: 1) a manuscript looking at differentiation of stem cells in a 3-D hydrogel system that encompasses silk and extracellular matrix proteins, 2) a manuscript related to the interactive effects of electrical signaling and the properties of the culture surface on cardiac stem cells specialization and 3) a manuscript assess changes to the mechanical properties and the extracellular matrix proteins as a function of congenital heart disease development and the role these changes play in promoting specific responses from cardiac muscle cells during prenatal growth.
